awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2018, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports research and training of the fellow that will utilize biological collections in innovative ways. Understanding why some animal traits evolve more rapidly than others is a fundamental goal of evolutionary biology. Reproductive traits are often among the fastest changing traits, but despite longstanding ideas about what drives their evolution, biologists still lack direct evidence of how these traits evolve in vertebrate animals such as mammals. The fellow will investigate how competition among males may drive changes in reproductive traits. First, the fellow will use lines of experimentally evolved house mice, in which changes in male reproductive traits have been documented, to determine whether male and female reproductive traits have evolved together. Second, the fellow will use recently developed methods to determine how fast these traits have evolved among species within a group of Australian rodents, and whether these changes have been driven by competition among males. This work will provide some of the first direct evidence about what drives the evolution of male and female reproductive phenotypes in mammals. It will also contribute to the toolkit available to scientists by establishing new methods for the study of evolution using museum collections. Finally, it will result in new international collaborations between scientists in the US and Australia, while training a new post-doctoral researcher in cutting edge methods.

	The fellow will investigate the hypothesis that the mammalian baculum has evolved via selection driven by male-male competition. First, the fellow will use experimentally evolved, wild-derived house mice to empirically determine whether and how female reproductive morphology co-varies with baculum shape. Second, using phylogenetic comparative methods and specimens from 63 species of muroid rodents, the fellow will determine the diversification rate of bacula and female reproductive tracts across a molecular phylogeny. Finally, the fellow will quantify the relative importance of male-male competition across Australian muroid rodents and determine its role in the evolutionary diversification of reproductive morphology. The proposed fellowship activities will significantly expand the fellow's range of research expertise with respect to both ideas and concrete skillsets, enabling a more integrative approach to the study of evolution and animal behavior in her academic career. Broader impacts activities are aimed at promoting the participation of indigenous peoples, who are underrepresented in post-secondary education and the sciences in both the US and Australia.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In many groups of mammals, males have a bone inside the penis called the baculum. Across groups of mammals, there is remarkable variation in the shape of this bone. In some species, it looks like a simple rod, in others more like a spoon, a spur, or a pitchfork. For more than a century, evolutionary biologists have been puzzled by the variation in this bone's shape. What causes this extraordinary diversity? Because of the bone's location within the penis, one prominent hypothesis has been that it evolves because of selective pressure related to mating. Perhaps certain bone shapes lead to better paternity success after mating (postcopulatory sexual selection).

            In this project, we applied new methods to the study of this old problem. We used a library of animal specimens housed in a natural history museum to study a group of rodents native to Australia. Many of the species we wanted to study are endangered in the wild, so using museum specimens let us research these questions without disturbing the animals in the wild. We used x-ray based imaging (x-ray microcomputed tomography; microCT) to make 3D scans of the mouse baculum and another bone, the patella (kneecap) that we used as a comparison trait. We used a recently developed computational method to align the scans to a common orientation and measure the differences in their shapes. Then, accounting for the evolutionary relationships between species, we asked how fast the bones were evolving.

            We found that closely related species tend to have more similarly shaped bones, while more distantly related species have differently shaped bones. There was also a correlation between the shapes of the baculum and the patella, which means that species with thicker, more robust bacula also tended to have thicker, more robust patellae. In general, the baculum was evolving about 1.5 times as fast as the patella, which is expected if sexual selection is driving the evolution of the baculum but not the patella. When we measured how fast the bones' shapes were evolving along each branch of the evolutionary tree, we found that there were very different patterns in baculum evolution than in patella evolution, with the rate of baculum evolution varying much more across the tree. That is, sometimes even very closely related species had very different bacula that were quickly evolving, whereas patella evolution tended to mirror the diversification rate of the tree as a whole. The included image shows the phylogenetic (~evolutionary) tree of the rodents studied in this project. Each tip of the tree shows a single species; for each, the purple shape shows the baculum, while the orange shape shows the patella.

            This project also had a broader impact. The funded postdoc, Dr. Tanner, worked in concert with the University of Western Australia's School of Indigenous Studies to increase participation in science among Indigenous students. Like Native Americans, Aboriginal Australians are underrepresented in higher education and science at every level. Dr. Tanner led hands-on activities that introduced more than 600 students in grades 8-12 to animal behavior, academic biology, and university campuses, with the goal of increasing student access to higher education and science.

 


Last Modified: 02/13/2023
Modified by: Jessie C Tanner

Image
  • This tree shows the evolutionary relationships between the rodents we studied. Each branch of the tree is labeled with the species' Latin name. We have included an image of the baculum (purple) and patella (orange) for each species.
    Image by Dr. Jessie Tanner
    Royalty-free (restricted use - cannot be shared)
    Jessie C Tanner
    Phylogenetic tree showing baculum and patella shapes
